pageProps.contentHtml:
module theory

Let AAA be an integral domain with field of fractions FFF. For an AAA-ideal a\mathfrak{a}a, prove that a\mathfrak{a}a is an AAA-projective ideal finitely generated over AAA if there exists an AAA-submodule b\mathfrak{b}b of FFF such that ab=A\mathfrak{a}\mathfrak{b} = Aab=A, where ab\mathfrak{a}\mathfrak{b}ab is an AAA-submodule of FFF generated by ababab for all a∈aa \in \mathfrak{a}a∈a and b∈bb \in \mathfrak{b}b∈b.
Solution.

Since ab=A\mathfrak{a}\mathfrak{b} = Aab=A, there exist a1,…,an∈aa_1, \ldots, a_n \in \mathfrak{a}a1​,…,an​∈a and b1,…,bn∈bb_1, \ldots, b_n \in \mathfrak{b}b1​,…,bn​∈b such that ∑i=1naibi=1\sum_{i=1}^n a_ib_i = 1∑i=1n​ai​bi​=1. For each iii, define f ⁣:a→A\func{f}{\mathfrak{a}}{A}f:a→A via a↦abia \mapsto ab_ia↦abi​ so that

a=∑i=1naaibi=∑i=1naifi(a).a = \sum_{i=1}^n aa_ib_i = \sum_{i=1}^n a_if_i\p{a}.a=i=1∑n​aai​bi​=i=1∑n​ai​fi​(a).

fif_ifi​ is well-defined as ab=A\mathfrak{a}\mathfrak{b} = Aab=A, and note that this implies a1,…,ana_1, \ldots, a_na1​,…,an​ generate a\mathfrak{a}a.

Now consider AnA^nAn with basis {e1,…,en}\set{e_1, \ldots, e_n}{e1​,…,en​}, and define π ⁣:An→a\func{\pi}{A^n}{\mathfrak{a}}π:An→a via ei↦aie_i \mapsto a_iei​↦ai​. Since the aia_iai​ generate a\mathfrak{a}a, this is a surjection. On the other hand, consider the map σ ⁣:a→An\func{\sigma}{\mathfrak{a}}{A^n}σ:a→An, a↦∑i=1nfi(a)eia \mapsto \sum_{i=1}^n f_i\p{a}e_ia↦∑i=1n​fi​(a)ei​. We have

(π∘σ)(a)=π(∑i=1neifi(a))=∑i=1naifi(a)=a,\p{\pi \circ \sigma}\p{a} = \pi\p{\sum_{i=1}^n e_if_i\p{a}} = \sum_{i=1}^n a_if_i\p{a} = a,(π∘σ)(a)=π(i=1∑n​ei​fi​(a))=i=1∑n​ai​fi​(a)=a,

i.e., π∘σ=id⁡a\pi \circ \sigma = \id_{\mathfrak{a}}π∘σ=ida​, so the sequence

0→ker⁡π→An→a→00 \to \ker{\pi} \to A^n \to \mathfrak{a} \to 00→kerπ→An→a→0

splits. Thus, a⊕ker⁡π≃An\mathfrak{a} \oplus \ker{\pi} \simeq A^na⊕kerπ≃An, so a\mathfrak{a}a is a direct summand of a free module, hence projective.
